You can continue to review the Hiragana here, until you feel completely comfortable with all of them. We strongly recommend using this app in conjunction with other learning materials, particularly those which use a \‘Spaced Repetition System\’ such as Duolingo or the popular Anki app. 
For detailed, up-to-date advice, you might like to check out these popular Japanese-learning sites: 

 https://www.reddit.com/r/LearnJapanese\ 
 https://www.tofugu.com/\

One of the most difficult things early on in your Hiragana journey can be distinguishing between some of the more similar-looking characters, such as あ and お. You may find this site useful in helping pinpoint the ways in which to tell such characters apart: 

 https://www.brighthubeducation.com/learning-japanese/54674-remembering-hiragana/ 

You might also want to try writing them out yourself, so that you can get a feel for the way they differ.

Pronunciation is unfortunately one thing that this app is not well-equipped to help you with, but do not despair! There is a wealth of information online for free about pronunciation of Japanese. Here are a couple that we thought were particularly good: 

 General Pronunciation: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WH0UX5oQVzM 

 The "ら、り、る、れ、ろ" sound: 
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6-ERE23YP88

While we do not think that writing Hiragana should necessarily be the focus for a beginning learner, we can nonetheless see the appeal of being able to reproduce the characters that you’ve spent so much time studying! In Japanese, there are normally guidelines on stroke orders when it comes to writing Hiragana, Katakana, or Kanji. 
Here is a guide to these stroke orders: 

 https://happylilac.net/hiragana-rensyu-1.pdf

So, you’ve learned all 46 Hiragana. Well done! That’s no small achievement. You’re now ready to really step up your Japanese learning. We would recommend continuing with your reviews here until you feel that you’ve got all 46 Hiragana down solidly. While doing so, you can start to focus more on other learning materials, such as those listed above. We would especially recommend one that incorporates Spaced Repetition, if you’re not already using one. A particularly popular (and free!) option is Anki, for which there is a dedicated community online that have made many well-designed decks. Again, we would recommend searching on: 
https://www.reddit.com/r/LearnJapanese\ for advice on some good decks. Anki itself can be found at this address: 

 https://apps.ankiweb.net/

Welcome to our Hiragana app! We look forward to learning with you. 

 Just before we begin, there's a few quick things we want to make you aware of…
\n While it is possible to complete the activities without audio, we would always recommend that you listen as you study, to better grasp the pronunciation of the different Hiragana.

\n We recommend using this app in conjunction with other Japanese learning apps. Since we\'re only covering Hiragana here, we would strongly advise using our app in conjunction with a broader Japanese learning app. That way, you\'ll be seeing Hiragana in complete words from the beginning!

While there are only 46 Hiragana, compared with thousands of Kanji, it is still important to note that it may take a couple of weeks of daily study before you've really got them hammered down. 

 Don't be afraid to focus on other areas of the language that you're struggling with now, and come back here when you're feeling ready!

With that out of the way, let's get started on learning! 

 Check out the info page if there's anything else you need help with. 

 がんばってね！

It's great to see that how fast you're getting through new lessons, but don't forget to go over what you've already learned! 
 Research shows that the most effective learning is done in small bites that are built on, so while it might be tempting to hurry through, we'd recommend doing a few more reviews first. 
Of course, you know what works for you, and if you're using another app for your reviews then that works just as well! We just thought we'd give you a heads up :) 

Keep it up!
